column1: The novel starts off with the disappearance of a young girl
column3: off the moors of a sleepy English village

column2: the reader realises this isn’t quite a mystery novel
column3: but something more aligned with McGregor’s debut novel

column1: What ensues are slice-of-life vignettes about the inhabitants of the village
column2: and though they are helpfully named (unlike in the aforementioned novel)
column3: I got terribly lost in the mire of characters and their relationships

column1: Perhaps the group of teenagers who were around the missing girl’s age stood out with greater clarity
column2: and their progress through their teenage years to early adulthood
column3: with their revolving door of couplings and breakups
column4: helped mark the passing of time in the otherwise timeless village
column6: faded from view and reappeared at seemingly inconspicuous moments of the novel

column1: While McGregor should be applauded for his ability to capture the pulse and rhythm of life in a rural community through his microscopic lens and his keen observation of the passing seasons and the details of the natural environs
column2: it felt like an overly long novel that should have stayed a short story
column3: with too large a cast of characters that causes the novel to lose its focus and direction

column1: What felt even more deceptive and distracting was the case of the missing girl in the first place
column2: which McGregor brings up periodically just as the press and media does throughout the decade or so of the the story’s timeline
column4: making the whole piece look like a landscape painting with no apparent focal point to draw the reader’s eye on
column5: which at best felt like a journal that just went on and on and on

column1: Given the brilliance of his debut novel
column2: I felt this was a letdown that showed you can’t use the same literary technique on any canvas
column3: even if it worked well for you that one time
